subject: Re: FW: Hello All,
msgSnippet: ... talking too ... Wow.  I still have a ways to go before that is the case. ... half-letters ... distinctive word ... I find it amazing how soon that word
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "Paige Gabhart" <pgabhart@s...>
wrote:

> I used it to take notes when in school when the professor got to
talking too
> fast for me to get in down in traditional orthography (TO).


Wow. I still have a ways to go before that is the case.


> I agree with you that the appearance of QS is quite appealing and that
> attracted me to it as well. I particularly like the use of the
half-letters
> in Senior QS as I feel they contribute to visual appeal and
distinctive word
> shapes that make word recognition easier.


I find it amazing how soon that word recognition happens. Very
exciting feeling when the word jumps at you complete.


> Regarding the use of QS as a form of shorthand: my understanding is
that
> shorthand is designed for making a record of speech spoken at
conversational
> speeds. That requirement means that proficient shorthand writers
tend to
> develop numerous abbreviations so that it is somewhat indecipherable
even to
> others who know that form of shorthand (Pitman, Gregg, etc.) In
addition,
> shorthands were specifically designed to be handwritten and really
were not
> suitable for printing. QS, on the other hand, although it is
excellent for
> handwriting, could also be printed by casting the letters in metal type
> using traditional printing methods. Now with computer fonts, QS has
been
> brought into the computer age.

> I would still like to see the development of an attractive QS font that
> permits easy use of the half-letters although some members believe
> half-letters should be restricted to handwriting.


I guess the present system is like that: Cursive is quite a bit
different visually from print fonts. I personally can see that it
would take a bit of effort (fun though it be) to learn how to read and
write QS, and I would be hesitant to have to learn a new way to type!

> Good luck with QS and welcome as a new member.

Thank you. I'll keep you posted on my progress!
